summary: Options contain inherent leverage that make them riskier than owning individual stocks and ETFs . As traders, it’s our job to identify those risks and put the odds back in our favor . Many options traders fail because they attempt to predict the future .  Discount brokers have been competing forcefully with one another, and all this competition has driven down rates . Individuals can now trade stocks for free in most cases, and options contracts cost just pennies on the dollar .  Options are generally not as liquid as stocks, and therefore the market maker attempts to realize a profit from the bid/ask spread . This spread is typically much wider for options as opposed to stocks . This makes it more difficult to trade options, particularly those with low volumes .  The AMZN July 18 160-strike call has a bid quote of 44.3 points and an ask price 44.9 points . As options cover 100 shares of the underlying security, the current asking price for interested buyers is $4,490 per contract . If you were to use a market order to purchase this call option, we’d expect to be filled at the ask price . Finding a market maker that is able to buy or sell at a more favorable price can result in significant cost savings .  Amazon appears to be resuming its longer-term uptrend, making it a good candidate for a call option purchase . Purchasing this option gives us the right to buy 100 shares of Amazon stock at $160 on or before the expiration date . Amazon is currently trading at $202.85/share .  The top (blue) row shows the performance of AMZN stock based on different percentage scenarios at expiration . The bottom (purple) row . shows the corresponding percentage return for our call option trade . A 15% increase in the stock price would yield a $3,042 profit . The illustration shows the inherent leverage that options provide .  The 1.75 points worth of time value (red box) equate to just 0.9% of the Amazon stock price . A good way to manage risk when buying call options is to minimize time value and maximize intrinsic value . Time value decays rapidly in the days leading up to option expiration .

Realty Income (O) is now trading at levels not seen since 2016, a nearly decade-long period of flat capital gains that’s tough to stomach for any investor . Highinterest ratesin recent years have prompted investors to seek higher-yielding alternatives . Yet, after this rough patch, the REIT is looking mighty appealing, boasting a sturdy 5.63% dividend yield .  Realty Income is securing long-term, stable leases with top-tier tenants, locking in steady cash flow . The company deployed $1.4 billion into investments, with a notable $893 million allocated to Europe at a 7.0% cash yield . While retail still dominates at 79.9% of their portfolio, they’re leaning into industrial properties (14.4%) and even dipping their toes into gaming and data centers .  Realty Income’s core portfolio remains a well-oiled machine, consistently generating dependable rental income . Long-term net leases, averaging 9.1 years, secure reliable tenants such as Amazon (AMZN) and Starbucks (SBUX)  Realty Income’s AFFO per share came in at $1.06, a 2.9% increase year over year . This steady growth reflects accretive investments that enhance shareholder value on a per-share basis . After years of underperformance, realty Income's stock now offers a compelling investment opportunity .  Realty Income has a 28-year track record of uninterrupted dividend growth . Since going public in 1994, the company has raised its dividend 110 times, often more than once per year . At $60.75, the 5.63% dividend yield is a rare figure for a Dividend Aristocrat .  Realty Income’s pullback to 2016 price levels presents a rare opportunity to acquire a high-quality REIT at a compelling valuation . With a diversified global portfolio, consistent AFFO per share growth, and a strong foundation for long-term performance, the company remains well-positioned for the future . For income-focused investors, this may be an ideal moment to secure reliable cash flow .

Gap CEO Richard Dickson says trade war headwinds have not stalled his turnaround . Dickson: "Like any business, we're constantly navigating complexity" Gap shares were pounded by about 20% Friday in the wake of its first quarter results .  The company is also doubling its vendor sourcing for American-grown cotton in 2026 . Gap is executing very well, delivering top-line consistency at Old Navy and Gap .  Gap's same-store sales have gained for five straight quarters . The company's total cash position surged 28% year over year to $2.2 billion . Gap says tariffs could cost Gap $250 million to $300 million this year .

Shares of Walmart have been on a roll since 2024's stock split, which was its first in over two decades . The stock zoomed up from a 52-week low of $64.16 in May of last year to a high of $105.30 this February . The company is finding sales success in high-margin areas such as digital advertising .  Walmart is already the largest retailer in the world by revenue . Online sales soared 22% year over year in its fiscal first quarter . Walmart Plus membership program provides free delivery and other perks for a fee .  Walmart's advertising business experienced a massive 50% year-over-year sales increase in Q1 . Part of the revenue growth is due to the retailer's foray into connected TV (CTV) Walmart acquired television maker Vizio at the end of 2024 .  Walmart's free cash flow (FCF) is another of the company's strengths, one that directly benefits shareholders . The retailer has generated over $10 billion in FCF in the last three fiscal years . Walmart kicked off its 2026 fiscal year with FCF of $0.4 billion, representing a nearly $1 billion increase .  Walmart spent $4.6 billion to buy back shares in Q1 . This is the largest share repurchase done in the past year . Walmart's forward P/E multiple shows it's a far better value than Costco's .  Walmart wasn’t one of The Motley Fool Stock Advisor’s top 10 stocks . The 10 stocks that made the cut could produce monster returns in the coming years . Walmart is well-positioned to benefit when economic conditions improve .  Foods Market, an Amazon subsidiary, is a member of The Motley Fool's board of directors . Robert Izquierdohas has positions in Amazon, Costco Wholesale and Walmart .

Prologis is the leader in logistics infrastructure REITs, with Amazon as its top client . The company has massive opportunities as e-commerce becomes more of a part of daily life . The dividend has increased at a strong pace, and that looks likely to continue .  Prologis is the leading logistics infrastructure REIT, with 5,900 properties and 6,500 clients . Its properties are built with green energy, such as electric charge points and solar installations . It operates in high-growth regions, with 86% of net operating income coming from the U.S.  Prologis sits at the intersection of e-commerce and retail, powering global supply chains . Amazon has spent the past few years completely revamping its fulfillment network to improve speed and lower costs .  Distribution center value and rent have both increased by a wide margin over the past 20 years . E-commerce is three times more space-intensive than physical retail . With $6.5 billion in liquidity, Prologis has the means to continue purchasing new properties .  Prologis' robust opportunities indicate that it should be able to pay and grow its dividend for a long time . It has a great track record, with a 180% increase in the dividend over the past 10 years, much higher than many other top dividend stocks . At the current price, Prologs' dividend yield is 3.7% -- an attractive yield for passive income investors . Singaporean insurtech company bolttech has integrated AWS generative AI solutions to lower costs of its operations and personalise customer services . The platform, "bolttech Gen AI Factory," has been developed using Amazon Bedrock and enhances the existing call centre platform .  AWS Singapore country manager Priscilla Chong stated: “We’re thrilled to support bolttech’s choice-based, model-agnostic approach is delivering AI-powered convenience to discerning customers at the forefront of the AI revolution . The company is already using AWS tools to expedite time to market .  Earlier in May 2025, bolttechentered a joint venturewith Sumitomo Corporation to offer device protection in Asia. access diverse model choices, deliver superior price-performance ratios, and robust trust and safety enterprise features .

Chase Coleman's Tiger Global Management fund made some major purchases of top artificial intelligence (AI) stocks during the first quarter . If a fund has over $100 million in assets, it is required to divulge its end-of-quarter holdings to the SEC .  During the first quarter, Tiger Global Management purchased a few big-time AI stocks . These included Microsoft, Amazon, Nvidia, and Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing . All four of these stocks were already in the fund's portfolio prior to Q1 .  Taiwan Semiconductor stock can be purchased for under 21 times forward earnings . This is a lower-than-market multiple, yet Taiwan Semi is expected to deliver monster growth over the next five years . Management believes its AI-related revenue can increase at a 45% compound annual growth rate (CAGR)  Wall Street analysts expect 53% revenue growth in fiscal year 2026 (ending January 2026) and 24% next year . Amazon isn't a revenue growth story; it's a margin expansion story . Microsoft is expected to grow revenue at a 14% and 13% pace in 2025 and 2026 .  While Microsoft has proven to be a strong and resilient business over the past few years, I don't think I'd want to own the stock as much as the other three . It's just as expensive as Amazon and Nvidia, yet it doesn't have quite the growth upside to justify the cost . Microsoft isn't abadAI stock to own, but it's at the bottom of my list for the four AI stocks Tiger Global Management bought this quarter . Tesla's electric vehicle sales are plummeting, and continued weakness could lead to massive losses for the stock . CEO Elon Musk believes self-driving cars and humanoid robots will eventually make Tesla the world's most valuable company one day . Today, those five companies areMicrosoft,Apple,Nvidia,Amazon, and Alphabet, and they have a combined market capitalization of $13.6 trillion .  Tesla is seeing plummeting demand for electric vehicles . Most of its revenue still comes from selling electric vehicles (EVs) Tesla can't grow production 50% per year if sales aren't keeping up . Deliveries plunged even further in the first quarter of 2025 .  Analyst estimates indicate Tesla might deliver as little as 350,000 cars during the second quarter, or a year-over-year drop of more than 20% . EV sales overall soared 28% across Europe in April . Chinese automakerBYDsaw 359% increase in sales across the region .  Last October, Tesla unveiled its long-awaited Cybercab robotaxi . It has no pedals or steering wheel because it's designed to run entirely on the company's Full Self-Driving (FSD) software . The unsupervised version of Tesla's FSD isn't approved for use on public roads yet .  Tesla CEO Musk says the company could generate $10 trillion in revenue over the long term . The company could be producing millions of robots annually by 2029 or 2030 . The Optimus robot could be used for dangerous jobs and repetitive tasks that humans don't want to do .  Tesla's stock is trading at an eyewatering price-to-earnings (P/E) ratio of 186.5 . Nvidia, Microsoft, Amazon, Apple, and Alphabet trade at an average P/E ratio of just 32.2: Tesla's earnings per share (EPS)plunged 71% during the first quarter of 2025 .  Tesla is destined for a sharp decline instead, bringing its P/E ratio in line with those of its big-tech peers . As a result, there is little hope the company will grow to exceed the combined value of Nvidia, Microsoft, Amazon, Apple and Alphabet anytime soon .
